required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Assess Screening for Diabetic Retinopathy Using Retinal Camera in Family Medicine Clinic
clinical_study.official_title: A Pilot Study to Assess Screening for Diabetic Retinopathy Using Retinal Camera in Family Medicine Clinic

brief_summary.textblock: The long-term goal for this study is to improve compliance of screening for diabetic retinopathy among subjects with diabetes. Researchers are also doing this research to determine the ability of appropriately trained family physicians to screen for and identify Diabetic Retinopathy using a retinal camera in addition to determining an overall patient perspective of the convenience and cost-effectiveness of retinal imaging within a primary care setting.

primary_outcome.measure: Family Physicians Screening for Diabetic Retinopathy - Number of photographs that are interpreted accurately by the family physicians when compared to the retinal specialist
primary_outcome.description: Number of photographs that are interpreted accurately by the family physicians when compared to the retinal specialist. These photographs are obtained using retinal imaging and after the initial read by the family physicians trained to interpret the images, the images will be reviewed by the retinal specialist to determine if the interpreted results are accurate.

secondary_outcome.measure: Screening Impact - Percentage increase in the screening rates for Diabetic Retinopathy using retinal imaging.
secondary_outcome.description: Percentage increase in the screening rates for Diabetic Retinopathy using retinal imaging using OPTOS when compared with the traditional dilated eye exam.The current screening rate is around 55%.

other_outcome.description: Percentage change in patient satisfaction and how much are patients willing to pay out of pocket to screen for Diabetic Retinopathy using retinal imaging. Each patient will be surveyed and these questions will help determine patient satisfaction and their willingness to pay for this versus usual care. We will ask the following questions: Did you find the Retinal Imaging an easy/efficient way of screening for eye disease as a result of having diabetes? Yes/No If you had to pay for this out-of-pocket what is the maximum amount you would be willing to pay? $25 $50 $75 $100 >$100 This will help us determine the patient's level of satisfaction and their willingness to pay out of pocket for the service.

arm_group.description: Intervention includes screening eye exam using Optos technology

intervention.intervention_name: Screening eye exam using Optos technology
intervention.description: Retinal imaging using Optos technology to identify Diabetic Retinopathy

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patient ≥ 18 years of age
- Diabetes Mellitus Type I or II
- Patient is willing and able to provide informed written consent
Exclusion Criteria:
• Known Diabetic Retinopathy
